hobby.message: Still chasing ghosts with analog photography?
Origami help keep the noise out?
Still dodging towers with those drones?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: City’s never simple. I fly drones, keeps me busy.
These days, too many eyes everywhere, even near the depot.
Graffiti mess pulled crowds. Not ideal for flying.
City’s… predictable. I do FPV drone races for focus.
That sunrise graffiti? More people started showing up, even at off-grid spots.
Lately, it’s made flying complicated. Too visible now.
Had to cut a session short last week.
Can’t complain. I spend off-hours flying FPV drones in abandoned areas.
It clears my head, especially after long shifts with the bands.
The new crowd at the graffiti wall? Makes things tense.
Was easier when it was just stray cats and silence.
I miss having the air to myself.
Honestly? I fly racing drones through old industrial ruins. Been doing it for years.
It’s a rush, better than any therapy. Good for stress.
But lately, the graffiti at sunrise drew people, sensors, even patrol drones.
On Sunday, police tagged my quad mid-dive—never happened before.
Guess my favorite spot isn’t off-grid anymore.
I stayed under the radar, but it’s trickier.
City changes, and the hobbies change too.
I’m wired for solitude. I race FPV drones—manual, nothing automated—mostly in forgotten sectors.
Started after my brother disappeared. Needed control, escape, wide open air.
Those spots were always quiet. I could fly for hours, hedge my thoughts.
Now, because of that graffiti, crowds and Directorate patrols show up by dawn.
Police drones lock down airspace, joggers record everything, rumors spread like RF interference.
I risked a loop Sunday, nearly flagged my BCI lower. Stayed low after.
Feels like the city’s watching every move—public or private, doesn’t matter anymore.
Hobby used to be invisible. Not lately. Not for people like me.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Freestyle FPV. Still flying.
Had to change locations lately. Crowds find my old spots.
Too many people hunting signals near the graffiti now.
Authorities hovering around. Makes flight time unpredictable.
Graffiti's changed everything. Not sure how long spots will last.
Right. Freestyle FPV clears my head.
I used to fly the depot at dawn. Quiet back then.
Now since the graffiti showed up, it's crawling with watchers and scanner signals.
Flight feels exposed. Even see Directorate quads marking no-fly areas suddenly.
Hard to just fly without tripping someone’s trigger now.
So yeah, I avoid old routes. Stay harder to follow.
Yeah, FPV freestyle. Only thing that shuts out the background noise.
Lately though, that’s changed a bit. The sunrise wall drew attention.
I flew it last week—place swarmed with crowds scanning the schematic graffiti.
Police drones started marking out restricted air. Every run flagged.
Feels weird. Used to have that place to myself.
Now you see all kinds—curious, nervous, some just spreading myths.
Makes flying less about flow, more about watching your own signal.
Freestyle FPV, yeah—my kind of silence. Always liked old depot roofs at dawn.
Now since Halden’s schematic popped up on that wall, it’s changed the whole energy.
You get sunrise, shifting colors, used to be me and motors only.
Now crowds flood in, tech scavengers, and Council drones sniffing the air.
I dodged three warning sweeps last flight. They’re tightening signal mapping there.
Honestly, doesn’t feel anonymous anymore. Even the flight logs are probably flagged now.
Lost my best route to people looking for signs.
Feels like the city’s watching you, even when you’re in the air.
Yeah, freestyle FPV is the only way I really reset—just signal and sky.
Been flying since my brother disappeared. It was our thing to spot the blind zones.
Closest place to clear thought was always sunrise over the depot wall—until the schematic hit.
Halden’s pattern on that wall sent the whole sector into panic mode.
Now the place is full of watchers, some pretending to be fans, others obvious security.
I pick up new scanner sweeps, weird police broadcasts, and more encrypted pings each time.
Used to only worry about weather, now flight logs get flagged, maybe tied to my score.
Most regulars dropped out recently, too risky or crowded.
Even when I’m flying free, it feels like the city’s inside your goggles, tracking every move.
